titleInfo.title: Fitness Consequences of Density, Spatial Arrangement, and Relatedness of Neighbors in a Dispersal Limited Invertebrate

mods:mods.abstract: In plants and sessile animals, the density, spatial arrangement, and genetic relatedness of conspecific neighbors differentially affect multiple components of fitness. However, the directions and magnitude of these effects are unclear due to differences between systems in the types of resources, the ways resources are acquired, how neighbors affect the local environment, and the mechanisms by which gametes are exchanged. In sessile marine invertebrates, much of the biodiversity contains species with relatively short (i.e., minutes to hours) larval durations and dispersal on relatively small spatial scales (i.e., meters). Limited dispersal in sessile animals potentially increase the chance that neighbors are kin, and decreases the chance of escaping conspecific competition. Using an experimentally tractable species (the bryozoan Bugula neritina), I performed a series of manipulative field experiments in which I tested the hypothesis that the density and relatedness of neighbors affects individual survival and growth across multiple time points, that relatedness of neighbors affects survival, growth, and reproductive output, and that the distance the nearest neighbor affects female reproductive output, paternity within broods, and competition among males. I found that: 1) increased density reduced survival but not growth rate, 2) there was no effect of relatedness on any component of fitness, in contrast to previous studies, 3) colonies produced more settlers without neighbors, and distance to the nearest neighbor did not affect the number of settlers produced or the degree of paternity. Only 12 out of 615 offspring were sired by colonies in the experiment, suggesting that sperm dispersal is greater than previously thought. In all cases where offspring were assigned to a candidate father, the paternal colony was always the closest colony. These results suggest that settling next to kin through limited planktonic dispersal may have limited consequences for individual fitness, and highlight the importance of not generalizing relationships between density, spatial arrangement, relatedness of nearest neighbors between taxa in different environments and mating systems or even within species.
mods:mods.note: A Thesis submitted to the Department of Biological Sciences in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Master of Science.
Scott C. Burgess, Professor Directing Thesis; Don Levitan, Committee Member; Alice Winn, Committee Member.
